props.synopsis: The NT government will no longer grant new permits to own a pet crocodile, leaving some "devastated" and the NT opposition saying it would "review" the new rules.

title.children: In the NT, owning a pet crocodile has become an election issue

image.altText: Tanya Plibersek sists smiling with her hand on her chin looking towards Anthony Albanese who is looking at a phone.

props.synopsis: Australia is soon to host an international "nature positive" summit, but the federal government can't get its own "nature positive" laws through parliament.

title.children: Overhaul of environmental laws looks shaky, with more delays and disagreements pushing back reform

image.altText: Two Chinese flags flutter in the wind at a shipping port.

props.synopsis: A prolonged downturn in China's property market will have significant flow-on effects for the Australian government's finances and the local steel industry, economists warn.

title.children: How a prolonged downturn in China's property market will have significant flow-on effects for Australia

image.altText: Ngaree Ah Kit speaks at a press conference with microphones in front of her.

props.synopsis: The Territory Labor party could face a $92,000 fine after one of its campaign flyers targeting an independent candidate in a key northern Darwin seat was found to be "inconsistent" with electoral laws.

title.children: Territory Labor distributes campaign flyer 'inconsistent' with electoral law ahead of NT election

image.altText: a woman and dog look into each other's eyes

props.synopsis: Desperate to ease the agony she was in and regain her quality of life, Inez made the heartbreaking choice to lose her fertility. It might not even help.

title.children: Inez had a hysterectomy at 27 for the chance of a pain-free life. The devastating catch is it might not help

image.altText: A box of packaged returned items is emptied by a woman onto a table.

props.synopsis: Plus-sized lingerie website Curvy is one of many online retailers pulling back on delivery incentives, with data showing fewer businesses are offering free shipping compared to six years ago.

title.children: Why online retailers in Australia are now charging for order returns

image.altText: A bald man wearing glasses and a suit gestures passionately.

props.synopsis: Not 10 days on from Australia's most senior spy advising politicians of all stripes to be milder with their language, the parliament has bunged on a multidirectional slapfest that wouldn't be out of place on the Jerry Springer show.

title.children: A loud and unnecessary immigration brawl is obscuring a deeper and genuinely alarming question

image.altText: Over-the-shoulder of a man's head you can see a desktop computer screen with Copilot chatbot home page

props.synopsis: A training provider says it believed the sexual harassment case study it used in a course delivered to Bunbury prison staff was fictional. In fact, it included the name and details of a former employee and current federal court complainant.

title.children: AI chatbot generates 'fictional scenario' using alleged victim's name at former workplace

image.altText: People swim in crystal blue waters of a creek surrounded by bush.

props.synopsis: Monday’s Four Corners program shone a spotlight on a little-known quasi-government body called the NT Land Corporation. Where did it come from? What power does it have? And what scrutiny is there?

title.children: What we know about the NT Land Corporation, a little-known body with big influence

image.altText: Birds fly out the front of Parliament House

props.synopsis: The federal government will be unveiling new laws to increase consequences for politicians and members of staff that engage in bad behaviour.

title.children: New legislation unveiled to increase consequences for MPs who engage in bad behaviour

image.altText: Brisbane residents speak about how much they're spending on groceries.

props.synopsis: National and state-based committees have been tasked with looking into supermarket prices across the country. But with costs continuing to outweigh inflation, whether they'll have an impact remains to be seen.

title.children: Despite multiple supermarket inquiries, Australians are struggling to keep pace with prices

image.altText: Mike Lynch smiles as he wears a suit and walks from the High Court.

props.synopsis: Their Italian holiday was meant to celebrate winning a mighty battle between corporate heavyweights, but the Bayesian luxury yacht was in "the wrong place at the wrong time".

title.children: Britain's tech tycoon had finally cleared his name and set sail for an Italian holiday. Then, nature struck

image.altText: Rows of people in military uniform stand in a field.

props.synopsis: The university where future leaders of the Australian Defence Force are sent to study has moved to limit research collaboration with China, including ending visits from academics to its Canberra campus, amid growing military tensions with Beijing.

title.children: Chinese academic visits banned at Canberra's Australian Defence Force Academy

image.altText: A crowd of people hold signs showing various faces, with a plume of yellow smoke in the foreground.

props.synopsis: The IDF says it has recovered the bodies of six hostages taken in Hamas' attack on October 7, 2023.

title.children: Bodies of six hostages recovered in Gaza operation, Israel military says

image.altText: A man sitting on a chair with both of his hands on his face.

props.synopsis: Joko Widodo has apologised not just once but twice in recent weeks as he prepares to step down as Indonesia's president. But what is he apologising for, and does he mean it?

title.children: As Joko Widodo relinquishes power, he says he's sorry for everyone he let down

image.altText: A group of people in formal suits stand at a press conference in front of a blue curtain

props.synopsis: The NSW branch of the Liberal party will not pursue legal action over last week's council nominations blunder, which cost close to 140 candidates a spot on the ballot in next month's local government elections.

title.children: NSW Liberals back down on legal threat after council nominations paperwork blunder

image.altText: A microscopic photo of pink bacteria swarming together

props.synopsis: Over the last three decades, legionnaires' disease has grown in Australia, particularly in NSW where cases have increased by over 600 per cent. Scientists aren't certain why, but they have theories.

title.children: Why is this 'first-world disease' becoming more common? Scientists aren’t certain

image.altText: A man with a beard holds a young child with houses in the background

props.synopsis: Edward Gilmore hoped to be living in his new home by the time his first-born child was ready to take his first steps. Four years after he signed the contract – and with an extra child now in tow – his family are finally moving in.

title.children: First home buyers left in the lurch after building company collapse finally moving in

image.altText: A tight head and shoulders shot of Senator Linda Reynolds looking at the camera outside court.

props.synopsis: A clumsily crafted bot network posting about the Linda Reynolds and Brittany Higgins defamation trial likely originated from foreign influencers wielding culturally divisive topics to sow discord, an ABC NEWS Verify analysis finds.

title.children: Seven red flags we identified about the X accounts posting about Reynolds's defamation trial

image.altText: A man wearing a suit, tie and glasses.

props.synopsis: Advisor to the prime minister of Qatar, Dr Majed Al-Ansari, has given a rare insight into the high stakes ceasefire negotiations taking place between Israel and Hamas.

title.children: Qatar hopeful of 'bridging gaps' in last-ditch attempt to reach ceasefire in Gaza

image.altText: An artist render of a concrete building.

props.synopsis: For decades, Victorians burned their rubbish in backyard incinerators. It's now back in vogue, with five waste-to-energy facilities under development across the state.

title.children: Waste-to-energy may be controversial, but five big Victorian projects are underway. How does it work?

image.altText: A woman puts her hand over her heart while smiling

props.synopsis: On a night that was meant to be a celebration of his bid for a second term, Joe Biden was moved to tears as he endorsed Kamala Harris. Here's what you missed from day one of the Democratic Convention.

title.children: On day one of the Democratic Convention, Kamala breaks with tradition to address the elephant in the room

image.altText: A man with sunglasses stands looking at the camera smiling

props.synopsis: Dougie Hampson died less than 24 hours after he was misdiagnosed with a cannabis-related syndrome and discharged from Dubbo hospital in August 2021.

title.children: Doctor's misdiagnosis led to 'preventable' death of Indigenous man

image.altText: Australian cyclist Matthew Richardson cheering in delight on his bike after winning a race

props.synopsis: Commonwealth Games gold medallist and Olympian Katherine Bates says cyclist Matthew Richardson's defection to Great Britain is "a break-up you never saw coming".

title.children: Australian athletes feeling 'ripped off' after cyclist's defection to Team Great Britain

image.altText: A composite image of two soldiers, soldiers firing a have weapon, and a brain scan

props.synopsis: Doctors suspect mysterious brain injuries in soldiers repeatedly exposed to blasts and explosions could be the cause of memory loss, headaches, fits of rage and an increased suicide risk.

title.children: How firing their own weapons has put Australia's soldiers at risk of brain injury

image.altText: King Charles walks through tributes left on the ground, teddy bears, flowers, balloons, mostly pink.

props.synopsis: King Charles III has travelled to Southport in northern England to meet the victims and families of the mass stabbing and the riots that followed, targeting Muslims and migrants in Britain.

title.children: King Charles visits Southport to meet those affected by stabbing

props.synopsis: In Australia, there are more than twice as many children as childcare places, according to a world-first study analysing childcare access down to the street level in nine developed countries.

title.children: Australia's childcare divide is growing. Here are the suburbs getting left behind

image.altText: A man with short black hair combed over to one side looks sternly at the camera while lightly sweating

props.synopsis: Video of the incident shows the former deputy premier hitting the reporter after she asks a question about the appointment of the country's new prime minister.

title.children: Influential Thai MP hits female journalist prompting calls for investigation

image.altText: Prabowo Subianto and Anthony Albanese shake hands during a press conference.

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announces Australia and Indonesia have finalised negotiations on an upgraded defence agreement which the federal government is hailing as the "most significant" pact the two countries have ever signed.

title.children: Incoming Indonesian president stresses 'non-alignment' after finalising defence agreement with Australia

image.altText: Herald Sun AFL and cricket writer Sam Landsberg has died.

props.synopsis: Tributes are pouring in for the 35-year-old Herald Sun and Fox Footy journalist, who has died after a traffic accident in Richmond on Tuesday morning.

title.children: Football journalist Sam Landsberger killed in collision at Melbourne intersection

props.synopsis: The Australian Securities and Investment Commission has released a report on how 15 of the country’s banks are responding to an unprecedented increase in scams.

title.children: New report finds bank scam victims bear the burden 96 per cent of the time

image.altText: Man working from home in a creative field on his ipad

props.synopsis: New laws come into effect next week that give workers the right to ignore work communications after hours, but they may not be enough to shift Australians' habit of working long hours.

title.children: Australians will soon have the right to switch off after hours — but it might not shift our 'excessive' work culture

image.altText: Still from Bluey Grannies episode with characters looking at coins fallen on the ground

props.synopsis: A second person has been arrested and charged by NSW Police over an alleged theft that saw more than half-a-million-dollars worth of limited edition Bluey coins stolen from a Western Sydney warehouse.

title.children: Second person charged over theft of $600k worth of exclusive Bluey 'dollarbucks'

image.altText: A man an woman share in a selfie in front of a bridge

props.synopsis: Ross Johnston looked after Christine like she was his granddaughter. When he came to collect her possessions from her country Victorian home he was floored by some of the stories her friends told him about their workplaces.

title.children: Christine worked in Australia to provide her Fijian family a better life. Her death sparked an international investigation
